Since $u^\mu_{\ ; \nu} = \Pi^{\mu\rho} u_{\rho;\nu}$, we have $\dot{u}^\nu =\Pi^\nu_{\ \rho} \dot{u}^\rho$ and it follows that the terms in \eqref{pressure_eqn} containing a $\Phi$ only have components in the space-like hypersurface orthogonal to the fluid flow $u$. Thus, since $\Pi_{\mu\nu}$ is a Riemannian metric on these hypersurfaces, \eqref{pressure_eqn} is an elliptic equation for the pressure term $\Phi$, from which we expect instantaneity and thus infinite speed of propagation. To be more precise, assuming that spacetime is foliated by the hypersurfaces orthogonal to $u^\mu$, we denote each such hypersurface by $\mathcal{O}_\tau$, where $\tau$ denotes the parameter of some integral curve of $u^\mu$. We assume initial data for $u^\mu$ at $\tau =0$ such that $\mathcal{O}_0$ is indeed orthogonal to $u^\mu$ with respect to the spacetime metric, then, prescribing suitable boundary values for $\Phi$ in $\mathcal{O}_0$, there exists a unique solution $\Phi$ of \eqref{pressure_eqn} by standard elliptic theory, c.f. \cite{Taylor}. However, for some $\tau > 0$, the structure of \eqref{pressure_eqn} on $\mathcal{O}_\tau$ has changed with the fluid velocity, which will in general result in a different solution $\Phi$ on $\mathcal{O}_\tau$ than on $\mathcal{O}_0$. Since \eqref{pressure_eqn} is an elliptic PDE, for which solutions are determined once boundary values are assigned, the change of $\Phi$ is instantaneous in each $\mathcal{O}_\tau$, which indicates that infinite speed of propagation is generally induced into the system \eqref{incomp_rel_Euler_simple1} - \eqref{incomp_rel_Euler_simple2}. 

To the best of my knowledge, the system \eqref{incomp_rel_Euler_simple1} - \eqref{incomp_rel_Euler_simple2} as well as equation \eqref{pressure_eqn} have not been derived before.
